abstractText: The present study explores the hydrogen-bond network in an equimolar mixture of acetic acid and water (AA–W). The investigation was conducted using a combination of neutron scattering and Density Functional Theory (DFT). New neutron scattering data at large scattering wave vectors were analyzed to determine the total structure factor SM(q) and the molecular form factor F1(q) of the system. DFT calculations using the 6-311++G(d, p) basis set were performed to optimize the monomers and various AA–W H-bonded clusters, including one acetic acid (AA) molecule connected to one, two, and three water molecules. Consequently, three dimers, three trimers, and one tetramer have been considered in order to describe the local order in the mixture. In addition, this study focused on the H-bond interactions in the most probable clusters in the solution, using the natural bond orbital and the atoms in molecules analyses. Our analysis particularly shows that stronger H-bond interactions occur in the ring structures. Published under an exclusive license by AIP Publishing. https://doi.org/10.1063/5.0171172

I. INTRODUCTION
Hydrogen bonding is of immense significance in aqueous solutions of organic compounds, influencing the properties of many biological systems.1–3 The formed hydrogen-bond networks between organic molecules and water deeply affect the mixture’s physical and chemical characteristics.4–6
In this context, acetic acid AA (CH3COOH) plays a crucial role as a simple prototype for studying O–H⋅ ⋅ ⋅O hydrogen bonds in organic compounds and providing valuable insights into these interactions in complex biological processes.7–9 H bonds in AA are formed between the hydrogen (H) atom of the hydroxyl (OH) group and the oxygen (O) atom of the carbonyl (C=O) one. While the formation of cyclic dimers has been confirmed in the gas phase,10–12 the short-range order in the liquid state is more complex13–18 and needs deeper investigation.
In our previous studies,19–22 we have explored the structural properties of liquid acetic acid using x-ray and neutron scattering
experiments, along with Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations and molecular dynamics simulations (DMs). These studies clearly highlight the presence of hydrogen-bond networks in the liquid. Crystal-like trimers have been found to well reproduce experimental data, and other molecular associations have been identified. Furthermore, it is widely recognized that water contains hydrogenbonded tetrahedral clusters.23 Therefore, it becomes crucial to investigate the molecular arrangements in the AA–W mixture and the competition between different O–H⋅ ⋅ ⋅O hydrogen bonds that might be formed.
The local order and structural features of acetic acid aqueous solutions have been extensively explored using various experimental and theoretical techniques. Rablen et al.24 conducted a pioneering study using computational methods to explore hydrogen-bonding interactions between water and acetic acid molecules. Their research revealed that acetic acid monohydrates adopt highly stable configurations by forming hydrogen-bonded rings that involve both the water molecule and the COOH group. The investigation of

the AA–W mixture using DFT calculations conducted by Gao and Leung25 reveals that a cyclic double hydrogen-bonded geometry is the more stable molecular model among the proposed structures for mono and dihydrate acetic acid. However, Pu et al.26–28 studied the interactions of an AA molecule with many water molecules using x-ray scattering data and IR frequencies. They suggest that, in dilute aqueous solutions, the potential structures involve two or more coordinate shells. Based on ab initio quantum chemical calculations and molecular dynamics simulations, Chocholoušová et al.10 reached the conclusion that acetic acid does not form any dimer structure in water solution. Lopes et al.29 investigated the complexes between AA and water by the ab initio method and IR spectroscopy in a nitrogen matrix to identify the first water complexes of the higher-energy isomer cis-AA. Raman spectroscopy studies30,31 have provided conflicting results, suggesting both the disruption of water structure by acetic acid hydrogen bonds and the formation of distinct micro-phases in equimolar AA–W mixtures. The research conducted by Takamuku et al.,16 based on wide-angle x-ray scattering and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), demonstrates that the strength of hydrogen bonds between acetic acid and water (AA–W), as well as between water molecules, increases progressively as the concentration of acetic acid (xA) decreases. In addition, Soffientini et al.32 carried out a neutron diffraction study of acetic acid hydration. Their results confirm that the tendency for direct interactions between acetic acid molecules is reduced in the presence of water. However, the authors state that the interpretation of the structure data presents some limitations, particularly in determining the relative importance of various hydrogen-bond types that occur in the solution.
The aim of the present paper is to provide a more comprehensive study of the local order AA–W mixture by collecting new neutron scattering data at a large modulus of the scattering vector coupled with DFT theoretical calculations. Specifically, we investigate an equimolar AA–W solution under ambient thermodynamic conditions. Neutron scattering data are used to find out the total structure factor. Experimental data, recorded up to 16 Å−1, allow us to determine with high accuracy the intramolecular conformation. Various molecular arrangements involving dimers, trimers, and one tetramer are then optimized by DFT calculations to identify the most probable model(s) that describe the short-range order of the solution. Furthermore, Natural Bond Orbital (NBO) and Atoms In Molecules (AIM) analyses are performed to gain insights into the nature and stability of the hydrogen-bond interactions in the retained clusters.

sections.heading: II. EXPERIMENTAL
sections.text:
The fully deuterated acetic acid (AA) was supplied by C/D/N isotopes (chemical purity 99% +, isotopic enrichment 99%). In the experiments, AA was used without further purification. The equimolar acetic acid–water mixture (AA–W) was prepared under dry atmosphere in a glove box in order to avoid contamination by atmosphere water.
The neutron scattering experiments were performed at the reactor Orphée of the Laboratoire Léon Brillouin in Saclay (France) using the 7C2 spectrometer. All details about this spectrometer are reported elsewhere.33 This spectrometer is equipped with a BF3 position sensitive detector with 640 cells; the angular step between two
adjacent cells is equal to 0.2○, which leads to a maximum diffraction angle of 125.15○. We select an incident wavelength of λ = 0.718 Å by means of a Cu(111) monochromator. The sample is contained inside a vanadium cell, which has an inner diameter of 3 mm and an outer diameter of 3.1 mm, as described in our previous publication.34 All experiments are carried out at 298 K. The usual measurements of the vanadium rod, the cadmium rod, and the empty cryostat were also performed.

The geometry optimizations of acetic acid and water molecules as well as the studied molecular clusters were carried out using the Gaussian 09 computational package.46 In these calculations, the 6-311G++(d, p) basis set and the B3LYP implementation of density functional theory47 were employed. The later technique is regarded as the better-suited approach for predicting molecular geometry and exploring physicochemical properties in hydrogenbonded environments.48–50 The optimized monomers and clusters are respectively used to compute the molecular form factor and the total structure factor. In addition, to gain further insights into the hydrogen-bond parameters, natural bond analysis51 was used to examine charge transfer or conjugate interactions within the retained molecular aggregates. This analysis involved the exploration of all potential interactions between the filled donor and the empty acceptor NBOs. Furthermore, in order to gain a deeper understanding of the strength of H-bonds within the more probable clusters in the mixture, AIM analysis is conducted using AIM 2000 software.52,53

This extended range allows a more precise determination of the intramolecular conformation, i.e., F1(q). As a result, the intermolecular interactions, especially the hydrogen bonds, can be deduced with enhanced reliability, as demonstrated earlier.

To analyze the intermolecular interactions, particularly the Hbond ones, in the more probable clusters in the equimolar AA–W solution, we conducted NBO and topological AIM analysis. In the hydrogen-bonded systems (D–H⋅ ⋅ ⋅A), NBO analysis highlights the charge transfer between the lone pairs of the proton acceptor (A) and the antibonding donor orbital σ∗(D–H). The stabilization energy E(2), determined using the second-order perturbation approach, quantifies the exchange of intermolecular charge from the donor’s filled orbital NBO (i) to the acceptor’s unfilled orbital NBO (j).56 A higher value of E(2) indicates a more stable interaction between the electron donor and acceptor. The second cyclic trimer T3 demonstrates three interactions that contribute to significant stabilization energies of 71.41, 14.6, and 17.15 kJ/mol. These interactions are respectively LP(2)O12 → σ∗(O4–H6), LP(1)O4 → σ∗(O5–H10), and LP(2)O3 → σ∗(O12–H13). In the cyclic tetramer TT, the transfer of electron density LP(2)O15→ σ∗(O4–H7), LP(2)O3→ σ∗(O5–H8), LP(1)O4 → σ∗(O6–H13), and LP(2)O3 → σ∗(O15–H16) displays the highest delocalization energies of 78.24, 21.88, 12.97, and 12.18 kJ/mol, respectively. In addition, the transfer of electron density from lone pairs of water oxygen to the antibonding orbitals of the AA hydroxyl group inside the ring structures (T1, T3, and TT) exhibits the highest values of the stabilization energies, which gives the cyclic cluster greater stability.
AIM topological analysis50 provides an efficient method for extracting the energetic properties of hydrogen-bonding intermolecular interactions. The H-bonds are characterized by the presence of critical bond points (BCPs) that meet the criteria established by Koch and Popelier.57–59 The molecular graphs of the T1, T2, T3, and TT models generated at the B3LYP/6-311++G(d, p) level are presented in Fig. 8. The topological parameters summarized in Table IV show that, for all the hydrogen bonds, the electron density ρc and the Laplacian of the electron density ∇2ρc are between 0.018 and 0.039 and between 0.07 and 0.126, respectively, satisfying the Popelier and Koch criteria.60 Figures 9(a) and 9(b) demonstrate a clear inverse relationship between the length of hydrogen bonds and the electron density ρc. Additionally, it reveals a similar correlation with the Laplacian electron density ∇2ρc. The obtained correlation coefficient values were 0.955 and 0.993, respectively, proving the strong association between these computed parameters. Furthermore, the OA–HA⋅ ⋅ ⋅OW–HW hydrogen bond interactions exhibit higher values of both ρc and ∇2ρc (Table IV). Higher ρc values designate a
concentrated electron density at the BCP, indicating stronger interaction between the oxygen atom OW and the hydrogen atom HA within the hydrogen bond. The elevated∇2ρc values further demonstrate a sharper electron density gradient, reinforcing the notion of a

stronger and more directional interaction in the OA–HA⋅ ⋅ ⋅OW–HW hydrogen bond interactions. The calculation of hydrogen-bond energy EH⋅ ⋅ ⋅O is performed using the method described by Espinosa et al.61 It is interesting to note from Table IV that the highest EH⋅ ⋅ ⋅O values are exhibited by the OA–HA⋅ ⋅ ⋅OW–HW Hbonds, followed by the HA=OA⋅ ⋅ ⋅HW–OW ones, which show intermediate EH⋅ ⋅ ⋅O values. Lastly, the HA–OA⋅ ⋅ ⋅HW–OW H-bonds exhibit the lowest EH⋅ ⋅ ⋅O values, providing evidence that they are the weaker ones.
Based on these findings, it becomes evident that the interactions occurring within the ring structures formed between the oxygen atom of water and the hydroxyl group of acetic acid (AA) are notably stronger than the other hydrogen bond interactions. These observations support the observed trend in both the NBO analysis and the DFT calculations and corroborate the fact that the cyclic trimers as well as the cyclic tetramer seem to better reproduce the local order of the mixture.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSION
sections.text: The reported results in this paper may be considered a detailed investigation of the structural properties of a deuterated equimolar acetic acid–water (AA–W) solution. Neutron scattering experiments at a large modulus of the wave vector in complementarity with DFT calculations and NBO and AIM analyses are conducted to elucidate the H-bond network in the system. By considering various molecular arrangements, we can identify the most probable clusters in the solution. Three dimers (D1, D2, D3), three trimers (T1, T2, T3), and one tetramer (TT) involving one AA molecule and, respectively, one, two, and three water ones are considered. Our results show a significant concordance between the experimental and theoretical structure factors derived from the trimers and the tetramer. Particularly, the cyclic clusters (T1, T3, and TT) show a higher level of agreement with the experimental data, suggesting their plausibility as the more probable intermolecular arrangements in the mixture. The DFT calculations, the NBO analysis, and the AIM analysis are strongly consistent. The formed H-bonds between the oxygen atom of water (OW) and the hydroxyl group of acetic acid (HA–OA) within the ring structures of the trimers T1 and T3, as well as in the tetramer TT, exhibit remarkable strength, the highest energy, and a large degree of stability compared to other H-bond interactions.
